content.title: Encephalitis
content.summary: Inflammation of the brain parenchyma causing neurological dysfunction, most commonly due to viral infection, characterized by altered mental status, fever, and focal neurological signs
key_points: Brain parenchymal inflammation with neurological dysfunction
Herpes simplex virus (HSV-1) is most common sporadic viral cause
Cardinal features: altered mental status, fever, headache, seizures
HSV affects temporal lobes - personality change, olfactory hallucinations
Empiric IV acyclovir (10mg/kg q8h) while awaiting CSF HSV PCR
CSF shows lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, normal glucose
MRI with temporal lobe hyperintensity highly suggestive of HSV

statement.text: Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain parenchyma resulting in neurological dysfunction, most commonly caused by viral infection (especially herpes simplex virus type 1). It presents with altered mental status, fever, headache, and often seizures or focal neurological deficits. HSV encephalitis characteristically affects the temporal lobes, and empiric treatment with high-dose IV acyclovir should be initiated immediately upon clinical suspicion, before confirmatory CSF HSV PCR results are available.
statement.formal: Encephalitis = Altered mental status + Fever + CSF pleocytosis + Brain parenchymal inflammation (clinical/MRI/EEG)

explanation.intuition: Encephalitis occurs when a pathogen (usually a virus) invades and inflames the brain tissue itself, not just the surrounding membranes (meningitis). Because the brain parenchyma is involved, patients develop confusion, personality changes, and focal neurological problems - symptoms that reflect damage to specific brain regions. HSV 'prefers' the temporal lobes due to its latency in the trigeminal ganglion and retrograde spread.
explanation.key_insight: The key clinical distinction is encephalitis vs encephalopathy. Both cause altered mental status, but encephalitis has CSF inflammation (pleocytosis) and brain inflammation on imaging/EEG, while encephalopathy (metabolic, toxic) has normal CSF and no inflammation. This distinction matters because encephalitis requires antimicrobial treatment while encephalopathy requires treating the underlying cause.
explanation.technical_details: HSV-1 reaches the brain via retrograde axonal transport from the trigeminal ganglion (oral herpes) or olfactory bulb. The medial temporal lobes and orbitofrontal cortex are preferentially affected due to their proximity to these entry routes. Necrotizing hemorrhagic inflammation causes the characteristic MRI findings. Without treatment, mortality exceeds 70%; with acyclovir, it drops to 20%, but many survivors have permanent sequelae.

definitions_glossary.encephalitis: Inflammation of brain parenchyma causing neurological dysfunction, typically from infection or autoimmune mechanisms
definitions_glossary.meningitis: Inflammation of meninges (membranes surrounding brain); presents with headache, neck stiffness, photophobia
definitions_glossary.meningoencephalitis: Concurrent inflammation of both meninges and brain parenchyma
definitions_glossary.herpes_simplex_encephalitis: Most common sporadic viral encephalitis, caused by HSV-1, affecting temporal lobes
definitions_glossary.temporal_lobe_encephalitis: Encephalitis preferentially affecting temporal lobes, classic for HSV, autoimmune (anti-LGI1)
definitions_glossary.acyclovir: Nucleoside analog antiviral that inhibits HSV DNA polymerase; first-line treatment for HSV encephalitis
definitions_glossary.csf_pcr: Polymerase chain reaction on cerebrospinal fluid to detect pathogen DNA; gold standard for HSV encephalitis diagnosis
definitions_glossary.pleocytosis: Elevated white blood cell count in CSF; lymphocytic in viral, neutrophilic in bacterial
definitions_glossary.arboviral_encephalitis: Encephalitis caused by arthropod-borne viruses (West Nile, Eastern Equine, Japanese encephalitis)
definitions_glossary.autoimmune_encephalitis: Antibody-mediated brain inflammation (anti-NMDA receptor, anti-LGI1, anti-GABA-B)
definitions_glossary.periodic_lateralized_epileptiform_discha: EEG finding seen in HSV encephalitis, suggesting focal temporal pathology
definitions_glossary.limbic_encephalitis: Encephalitis affecting limbic structures (hippocampus, amygdala) causing memory and behavioral changes
definitions_glossary.postinfectious_encephalitis: Immune-mediated brain inflammation following systemic infection (ADEM)

pathophysiology.mechanism: Viruses reach the CNS via hematogenous spread (arboviruses), retrograde axonal transport (HSV via trigeminal/olfactory), or direct invasion. Once in the brain, viral replication causes direct cytopathic effect and triggers immune-mediated inflammation. HSV-1 characteristically causes hemorrhagic necrotizing encephalitis of the temporal and frontal lobes.
viral_neurotropism: Rabies: Brainstem and limbic system (motor neurons)

immune_response.innate: Microglial activation, type I interferon response
immune_response.adaptive: CD8+ T cell response clears infected neurons (may cause collateral damage)
immune_response.autoimmune: Post-infectious molecular mimicry or paraneoplastic antibody-mediated

clinical_presentation.altered_mental_status: Required - confusion, personality change, decreased consciousness
clinical_presentation.fever: Present in majority but may be absent

hsv_encephalitis_features.prodrome: Fever, headache, malaise for days before neurological symptoms
hsv_encephalitis_features.temporal_lobe_signs: Behavioral changes, memory impairment, olfactory/gustatory hallucinations
hsv_encephalitis_features.progression: Rapid deterioration over days without treatment

diagnostic_workup.lumbar_puncture: CSF PCR for HSV, VZV, enteroviruses; cell count, protein, glucose
diagnostic_workup.mri_brain: T2/FLAIR hyperintensity in temporal lobes (HSV); DWI restricted diffusion early
diagnostic_workup.eeg: Periodic lateralized discharges (PLEDs) over temporal regions
diagnostic_workup.serology: Arboviral IgM, autoimmune encephalitis antibody panel

acyclovir.timing: Start immediately on clinical suspicion - do not wait for PCR

adjunctive_therapies.seizure_management: Antiepileptic drugs for acute seizures; prophylaxis controversial
adjunctive_therapies.cerebral_edema: Hyperosmolar therapy, head elevation, possible decompressive surgery
adjunctive_therapies.immunotherapy: For autoimmune encephalitis - steroids, IVIG, plasma exchange, rituximab

definition.@value: Inflammation of the brain parenchyma causing neurological dysfunction, characterized by altered mental status with evidence of brain inflammation on CSF analysis, imaging, or EEG

skos.scopeNote: Covers infectious and autoimmune encephalitis; excludes metabolic encephalopathy and primary psychiatric disorders
skos.example: A 55-year-old woman with 3 days of fever, confusion, and behavioral change; MRI shows left temporal lobe T2 hyperintensity; CSF has 85 WBC (95% lymphocytes), protein 78, glucose 55; HSV PCR positive; treated with IV acyclovir

learning_objectives: Differentiate encephalitis from encephalopathy based on clinical and CSF findings
Recognize the clinical presentation of HSV encephalitis including temporal lobe signs
Initiate empiric acyclovir immediately on clinical suspicion before confirmatory testing
Interpret CSF, MRI, and EEG findings in encephalitis
Describe the expanding role of autoimmune encephalitis in differential diagnosis
clinical_pearls: Start acyclovir IMMEDIATELY on suspicion - don't wait for HSV PCR (takes 24-48 hours)
Temporal lobe involvement (behavioral change, olfactory hallucinations) = think HSV
Normal initial MRI doesn't exclude HSV - may take 48-72 hours for changes
CSF HSV PCR can be falsely negative very early - repeat in 3-7 days if high suspicion
Young woman with psychiatric symptoms + seizures = consider anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis
Distinguish encephalitis (CSF abnormal) from encephalopathy (CSF normal, metabolic cause)

board_yield.usmle_step2: Very High - HSV encephalitis diagnosis and treatment

common_misconceptions: Wait for HSV PCR before starting acyclovir (false - start immediately on suspicion)
Normal MRI excludes HSV encephalitis (false - may be negative early)
Encephalitis always presents with meningeal signs (false - may have minimal meningism)
Autoimmune encephalitis is rare (false - increasingly recognized, may equal viral)
